text_fields.value: Let's annotate already!

text_fields.name: text
text_fields.value:
Right, so you've probably figured that all those question things can also be used for annotating texts and images. But there are some special annotation features as well.

  One we quite like is the Annotinder function. If you're on mobile, you can swipe this one!

If you're on desktop, you can also use the arrow keys.

text_fields.name: title
text_fields.value: Training questions

text_fields.name: text
text_fields.value: This is a training unit that you can add at the start of a codingjob. The difference from normal units is that the coder will be shown whether an answer is correct. If the answer was wrong, the coder needs to retry the question

text_fields.name: title
text_fields.value: Training questions

text_fields.name: text
text_fields.value: Training units, but with multiple questions per unit

text_fields.name: title
text_fields.value: Gold questions

text_fields.name: text
text_fields.value: This is a test unit. If the coder gives the wrong answer, a specified amount of damage is received. Bad coders can then be disqualified. Receiving damage (by default) happens silently, so that the coder doesn't know which questions were gold questions.

text_fields.name: title
text_fields.value: Span annotation mode

text_fields.name: text
text_fields.value:
There is also a mode for annotating words or a span of words. This is more of an expert coder task, and can be done most efficiently with mouse or keyboard. With a mouse you just click and hold to select. With keyboard you use the arrows to navigate and hold spacebar to select.

You can also do this on mobile though. Tap the same word twice to begin a selection, and then tap another word to finish a selection

text_fields.name: title
text_fields.value: Span annotation edit mode

text_fields.name: text
text_fields.value:
Instead of open annotations, you can also pre-annotate spans and only let coders edit them. You could for instance first use a dictionary and then let coders validate or correct the annotations. Or add empty placeholder and let coders fill in the blanks.

This way, span annotations tasks can be made more mobile friendly

markdown_fields.name: markdown
markdown_fields.value:
# When can we use this?

Almost! The core features are there, and at the moment we're mainly cleaning up and improving the codebase.

If you are interested, we'd love to hear your thoughts. The goal of this project is to create an annotator dedicated to the type of annotation tasks that we encounter in our field, and to experiment with different approaches and interfaces to see how they might affect speed and quality of annotations.

We are sure many of you have had good and bad experiences with annotation tasks, so we'd love to learn from them
